awd_titl_txt: Advancing Science and Technology in Eastern Oregon
awd_abstract_narration:
This National Science Foundation (NSF) Scholarships in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (S-STEM) project at Eastern Oregon University (EOU) will provide scholarships and support services to academically-talented students majoring in biology, chemistry-biochemistry, computer science, and mathematics who demonstrate financial need. EOU is a 4-year, public institution serving economically and technologically disadvantaged rural communities across Oregon. Thus, the project will recruit potential scholarship recipients via visits to local high schools and community colleges, as well as community outreach to other Pacific Northwest regions and events that bring prospective students and parents to the EOU campus.

The main goals of the Advancing Science and Technology in Eastern Oregon (ASTEO) S-STEM project are to (a) increase the enrollment of academically talented students with financial need in STEM majors; (b) increase retention and graduation rates, while reducing time to graduation, for ASTEO scholars relative to similar populations within the university; (c) increase the number and diversity of STEM graduates from EOU who enter and remain in the STEM workforce or enter graduate school in a STEM discipline; and (d) contribute to regional economic development by preparing well educated graduates who enter STEM-related professions. The program will support a total of 23 students, including 11 incoming freshmen (four-year awards) and 12 transfer students (two-year awards). Key elements of the program will include opportunities for residential students to live together; a freshman seminar; academic support services; faculty and peer mentoring; high-quality enrichment activities; opportunities for research and internships; and a STEM Ambassadors program, in which more senior ASTEO scholars serve as peer tutors and participate in recruiting, mentoring, and networking for the S-STEM project. Evaluation of the success of the project will inform institutional practices for recruiting, design of first-year courses, and student enrichment and academic support services.

por.por_cntn:
The Advancing Science and Technology in Eastern Oregon (ASTEO) project was funded in 2015 by the NSF Scholarships in Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics (S-STEM) to implement a five-year program to recruit, retain, and graduate a cohort of 18 talented, economically disadvantaged students majoring in biology, chemistry and biochemistry, mathematics and computer science.  The project also intended to explore different interventions based on published STEM education best practices to assess their effectiveness in promoting student success. 

The specific goals of the project were to: (a) increase enrollment in STEM majors from financially needy, academically talented students; (b) provide support and mentoring services for ASTEO scholars; (c) increase retention and graduation rates for ASTEO scholars relative to similar populations within the university; (d) reduce graduation times for ASTEO scholars relative to similar populations within the university; (e) increase the number of STEM graduates who enter and remain in the STEM workforce or enter graduate school in a STEM discipline; (f) contribute to regional economic development goals by preparing well educated graduates who enter a STEM-related profession.  

The recruitment efforts exceeded the originally planned cohort of 18 as we were able to recruit 39 students to the program thanks to a fee remission agreement within the university that expanded our ability to recruit students and support them until graduation.  New scholars were admitted to the program as recently as Fall 2022.  However, the diversity of the applicant pool was limited and efforts to recruit transfer students from community colleges turned out to be challenging.  Analysis of the 2016-2018 classes shows that the four-year graduation rate for ASTEO scholars are significantly higher than the control group (74% ASTEO vs. 40% control), indicating that the program has a strong positive impact on the ability of students to persist in their degree program and successfully graduate.  

Data also supports that the interventions used in this project have been successful in retaining and graduating scholars when compared to a similar control group.  These included: advising by faculty in the discipline of the major starting immediately upon admission to the program; a year-long freshman seminar that included a mini-internship; an opportunity for residential students to live in proximity in the dorms; enrichment activities such lectures by guest speakers and field trips; opportunities for research and internships; and academic support services such as peer mentoring and tutoring.  Based on exit interviews, the STEM seminar sequence and the mini-internship experience were among the most effective and valued interventions in the program.

The program also provided opportunities for scholars to engage in research and other professional experiences including attending and presenting at regional and national meetings, exploring different career paths and giving back to the community by helping organize and implement outreach events geared at promoting STEM to underserved populations in northeastern Oregon.

All ASTEO scholars that have graduated from the program so far are either employed or are currently pursuing an advanced degree in a STEM field.

In conclusion, the Eastern Oregon University S-STEM scholarship program has been successful in recruiting applicants, awarding scholarships, and conducting all the planned program activities. Based on the number of graduates from the program that enrolled in graduate school or entered the workforce, the program was effective in building a pipeline to the STEM workforce.  The interventions utilized during the project had a positive impact on the success of the scholars and have been incorporated in our STEM undergraduate programs.

 


Last Modified: 09/29/2022
Modified by: Anna G Cavinato
